column123: The Department for Energy Security and Net Zero manages the radiological response and emergency management system (RREMS) on behalf of all government departments and agencies who would be involved in a radiological and nuclear incident. RREMS replaced RIMNET as the primary system in 2022, and RIMNET has subsequently been decommissioned.

column131:
On-the-Job-Training (OJT, around 1-3 months) in IAEA Partner Laboratories and Capacity-building activities in the following areas:
•	Sampling, radiochemical processing, and measurement of various radionuclides (e.g., Tritium, Stronium-90, Plutonium) in various environmental media
•	Setting-up, operation, maintenance (including basic troubleshooting), and analysis of radionuclides using gamma spectrometer, liquid scintillation counter, and alpha spectrometer
•	Establishment, operation, maintenance, and analysis using in-situ radioactivity measurement techniques (in-situ gamma ray spectrometry, in-situ monitoring of radioactivity in aquatic and marine waters, stationary air monitoring)
•	Radioactivity data analysis (statistical treatment) and dose estimation

column114: Following EU legislation, there is an Environmental Radiological Surveillance Net around our territory (Spain). The Legal Authority ( CSN) funds this network. The universities and research institutions in our country take samples and measure radionuclides. There are more than 14 stations in REM- NET.  The type of samples and frequency are established. The stations take samples of soil, sediment, air, biota, and food. Mainly they measure Cs137, gross alpha, gross beta, I-131, and Sr90.

column97: Since 1994, the Environmental Control Laboratory regularly participates in intercomparisons carried out by different institutions. Until 2018 it had participated in more than 30 intercomparisons in different matrices, including: water, soil, vegetables, grass, pine needles, filters, air and ashes. The radionuclides involved were gamma emitters, gross alpha and  gross-beta, tritium, Rn-222, transuranic elements, uranium, Sr-90, Po-210 and Ra-226. The intercomparison exercises were organized by the following organizations: Laboratoire D’Analyses de Biologie Medicale de Commissariat a L’Energie Atomique (CEA) / Centre d’Estudes de Valduc - Direction des Applications Militaires (DAM), France Environmental Measurements Laboratory (EML), USA American Association of Radon Scientists and Technologists-(AARST), USA National Radiological Protection Board (NRPB), Bundesamt für Strahlenchutz- Federal Office for Radiation Protection (BFS),  Health Protection Agency (HPA) UK, UK National Health Laboratory (NPL), International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) USA, CSN-CIEMAT Spain, CNEA- Gcia de Área Seguridad Nuclear y Ambiente-Gcia Gestión de la Calidad- Interlab, Argentina, AIRP, ARPA, FANR and ENEA, Italy. The frequency according to 17025 ISO Standard is, at least, 1 in 4 years for the whole technique.
column99:
Some of the main aspects are listed below. 
- A fundamental aspect regarding quality assurance of measurements is the regular participation in intercomparison exercises or proficiency test programs organized by laboratories with international recognition (International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), National Physical Laboratory (NPL), National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST). 
- Calibration of the measurement systems according to each laboratory using calibration sources or certified reference materials from internationally recognized laboratories. 
- Preparation of control charts to verify that equipments measure correctly. 
- Verification of background measurements for the measurement system. 
- Verification of detection limit of techniques in case of bakground variation. 
- Recording of technical maintenance carried out regularly. 
- Verification of robustness by using NIST traceable standards, when changing for example the batch of Liquid Scintillation Counter cocktails. 
- Verification of micropipettes used. 
- Determination of chemical efficiency for sample batches, for example for Sr-90 analysis. 
- For techniques that are validated, a validation of the method will be carried out in successive stages by laboratory analysts, evaluating the following variables according to the experimental results obtained in terms of: Accuracy, Intermediate Accuracy, Repeatability, Reproducibility , Robustness, Minimum Detectable Concentration. 
- Accreditation of laboratories under ISO 17025 Standard started in 2006 to demonstrate that there is a quality management system and the laboratories are technically competent to generate valid results.
The Environmental Control Laboratory has the following techniques accredited under ISO 17025 Standard: Determination of gamma emitters in waters; Determination of uranium in waters by fluorimetry and kinetic phosphorescence; Determination of tritium in waters and milk and the Determination of Strontium-90 in waters.

column114: Air and dose rate sampling stations around NPP belong to licensees, and ARN verifies the monitoring. ARN has 1 station in the atomic centre (radioisotopes production facility and fuel fabrication) for aerosols and gaseous iodine, and a background station for aerosols and humidity condensate monitoring.
column118: Around NPP and atomic centres with TLD detectors, not automatically.
column121: Emergency exposure situations: ad-hoc monitoring is prepared (air monitoring, soil, water, milk and food samples, dose rate monitoring). Around nuclear facilities: aerosols monitoring (annually); dose rate (integrated every six months); humidity condensates (weekly); milk (monthly); soils and sediments (annually); food (sampled monthly and measured every 3 months as pools); fish (sampled monthly and measured every six months as pools); waters (monthly). Existing exposure situations (e.g. uranium legacy sites): uranium sites are not considered legacy sites as they are under regulatory control. Environmental monitoring is performed once a year (uranium and Ra-226 analysis in waters (surface, drinking waters, aquifer) and radon emantion rate from the tales). Also radon in air in the surroundings and dwellings.
column126: The Nuclear Regulatory Authority is the authority for environmental monitoring around nuclear installations (planned, existing and emergency situations). The National Atomic Energy Commission is the authority and performs the measurements for the import/export of foods.

column99:
1. Efficiency Calibration: Using Laboratory Sourceless Calibration Software (LabSOCS) for efficiency calibration, which models the detector response based on the sample's chemical composition and geometry.
2. Inter-laboratory Comparison: Collaborating with the State Key Laboratory of Environmental Geochemistry (SKLEG/IGC, CAS) to perform parallel measurements and correct the HPGe gamma-spectrometry system efficiency.
3. Use of Certified Reference Material: Employing a standard reference source material (Catalog No. 7500 from the Isotope Products Laboratories, USA) containing the fallout radionuclides (FRNs) of interest.
4. Proficiency Testing: Participation in international proficiency tests organized by the IAEA to validate the laboratory's performance and ensure the accuracy of determination results.
5. Standardized Sample Preparation: Implementing a consistent sample preparation protocol (air-drying, sieving, weighing, and packing into standardized Plexiglass containers) to minimize introduced variability.

column31: Training can be made available for all  analysis performed in our lab as mentioned before plus quality management systems, as our lab is ISO 17025 accredited since 2017. Training includes the following techniques: alpha spectrometry, gamma spectrometry, liquid scintillation counting tech, as well as natural uranium and thorium analysis by Q-ICP-MS. We are able to host hands-on training up to 4 months/year.

column116: There are 8 on-line monitors for alpha/beta and gammaspectrometry measurements in airdust. Furthermore, there is one high volume sampler (around 800 m3/h) with on-line gammaspectrometer.
column118: There are 160 on-line gamma dose rate monitors
column121: Countrywide, on a regular basis: surface waters. Sampling and analysis is carried out by RWS, the Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management. Around nuclear facilities: network around NPP Borssele giving on-line gamma dose rates. Drinking water measurements are performed by multiple commercial laboratories. Food, feed and milk are measured by Wageningen Food Safety Research (WFSR).

column132:
The IAEA's ALMERA network strengthens the capabilities of laboratories that perform environmental radioactivity measurements by promoting harmonized methods, interlaboratory exercises, and preparedness for radiological emergencies. Its main value is ensuring that countries have competent, comparable laboratories capable of generating reliable data under both routine and emergency conditions.

A diagnostic survey allows for the precise identification of each laboratory's equipment, personnel, methods, accreditations, and limitations, revealing gaps and opportunities. This information facilitates prioritizing technical assistance, guiding IAEA projects, defining national monitoring and modernization capacities, and strengthening inter-agency cooperation. Overall, the survey is a key tool for planning improvements, optimizing resources, and consolidating the national analytical network in alignment with ALMERA standards.

column81: radiochemical method (routine) of Sr-90 determination based on oxalate precipitation of Ca and Sr; heating to oxides and the usage of aluminum as Y-90 carrier. The equilibrium is achieved in 18 days; and after that time Y-90 is isolated on the Al(OH)3 carrier; which is then ignited to an oxide that is subsequently measured by proportional counter.

column97:
We use certified gamma reference standards (e.g., Ba-133, Cs-137, Co-60, Eu-152), mostly purchased from the Czech Metrological Institute and other accredited suppliers.
When needed, we also use reference materials shared through collaboration with Vinča Institute, the University of Novi Sad (Department of Physics), and the Faculty of Veterinary Medicine in Belgrade.
Due to limited funding, certified standards are purchased periodically, while additional materials are obtained through cooperation with partner laboratories.
column99: Internal quality control program is composed of day-to-day monitoring of analytical performance. HPGe detectors: Equipment performance is verified on a regular basis, every week, using Gamma Vision Software. Energy calibration in a whole region of energies is checked before applying the QC procedure, which includes measurement of the detector-shield background, total activity, peak shape, and peak drift. These parameters are tracked with warning and acceptance limits (long term trend is analysed). A Co-60 point source is used for that purpose. Results of the QC are stored in a database and can be displayed and charted. Gas proportional counter: before every analytical batch, the background count rate and efficiency of the counter are checked (alpha efficiency with Am-241 and beta with Sr-90/Y-90 source). Gamma-spectrometry method: internal QC covers analysis of control samples - certified reference materials, reference materials or laboratory control samples according to the appropriate plan and program of quality control. Internal quality control method is performed through blank measurements and measurements of a control sample before each set of samples to check the accuracy and precision of the method. For control samples, the Laboratory uses reference materials and samples obtained through ALMERA intercomparison exercises. Sr-90 radiochemical method: internal QC is run with each analytical batch and consists of method blank analysis and analysis of duplicates (additional replicates of samples that are subjected to the same procedure as the original sample). The Laboratory also regularly uses reference materials containing certified amounts of the target radionuclide (LCS) to check the accuracy and precision of the method (whether the results achieved during the validation of the method are maintained).

column97: IAEA: once a year since 2000; NPL: once a year since 2012; IRSN: 1 or 2 per year since 2010; LGC aquacheck: 5 per year since 2012; ERA (US): 2-3 per year since 2014; Sike (Finland): once every 2 years since 2014; IRMM: once every 2 years since 2000.
column99: Any analytical equipment (eq. HPGe, LSC, ICP) are checked before analyzing routine samples (1st level QC). Any routine samples in a batch are measured with a QA sample in parallel (reference material or old PT sample) (2nd level QC). For each analytical procedure under accreditation or under development, the laboratory participates in proficiency tests (around 120 parameters are tested annually) (3rd level QC). Each batch of sample is validated by a technical responsible. Each test report is reviewed by the labo supervisor before release to the customer.

column97:
Usually standards delivered by the Czech Metrology Institute or samples from interlaboratory comparisons.

We have been an ALMERA member since 2007 and we participate in the ALMERA comparisons almost every year: IAEA-CU-2008-04, IAEA-CU-2011-04, IAEA-TEL-2012-04, IAEA TEL-2014-04, IAEA-TEL-2014-01, IAEA-TEL-2015-04, IAEA-TEL-2016-04, IAEA-TEL-2017-04, IAEA-TEL-2018-04, IAEA - TEL-2019-04, IAEA-TEL-2020-04. We have participated annually in comparisons organized by the BfS in the field of internal contamination since 2011, and also regularly participate in comparisons organized by EC (JRC, ISPRA) - 2003, 2004, 2008, 2010, 2011, 2012, 2014, 2017, 2020.
column99: According to the requirements of the ISO 17025 and Czech Legislation Act No. 263/2016 (Atomic Act) and Decree No. 422/2016 on radiation protection and security of a radioactive source. column132: For future PTs it would be helpful if samples being sent to Australia were dispatched earlier. The sample shipment to ANSTO which was dispatched from Seibersdorf in early July arrived in Australia nearly a month later on 6 Aug 2025 and required further irradiation because Australian customs/quarantine require 50 kGy irradiation and PT samples are treated prior to shipment at 25 kGy. The PT shipment was released to ANSTO after irradiation on 20 Aug leaving 6 weeks for multiple analyses.

column97:
The laboratory uses reference materials (RMs) and standard sources for calibration and quality control purposes. These include:
•	Standard gamma sources (Multinuclide Standard Source) such as Cs-137 and Co-60for energy and efficiency calibration of the HPGe gamma spectrometry system.
•	Americium-241 (Am-241) for efficiency calibration.
•	Strontium-90 (Sr-90) for efficiency calibration.
•	Quenched H-3 Standards Set (10 vials) for efficiency calibration.
•	Unquenched Liquid Scintillation Standards Set (C-14, H-3, and background) for calibration and performance verification of the liquid scintillation counting system.
column99:
The laboratory has established internal QA/QC procedures to ensure the reliability and accuracy of measurement results. These include:
•
Routine instrument performance checks and energy/efficiency calibration using standard sources.
•
Background and stability checks performed periodically.
•
Analysis of quality control samples and duplicates to verify measurement precision and accuracy.
•
Regular participation in internal cross-check measurements among laboratory personnel.
•
Maintenance and calibration records maintained according to the laboratory’s quality manual.
column101: The laboratory uses the IAEA decay data library for radionuclide identification and activity calculation. The decay data are consistent with internationally evaluated nuclear structure and decay data recommended by the IAEA Nuclear Data Services (NDS).
column102: The laboratory performs experimental calibration of the HPGe gamma spectrometry system using certified standard gamma sources. Energy and efficiency calibrations are carried out with multinuclide standard sources (e.g.Cs-137,Co-60, and mixed gamma standards) under the same geometry as the routine sample measurements.
column110:
Discharges from the nuclear facilities (NPPs, waste repositories)
Around Radioactive waste storage facilities
column114: A network of sampling stations were carefully selected and several requirements were taken into consideration during the site selection to ensure that environmental samples from those areas would be appropriate representatives. Such network has been established for installing high volume air samplers, fallout containers, and OSLs to collect air particulates, fallout, and radiation doses, respectively, and for sampling other terrestrial and marine environmental samples for radioactivity measurement.
column116: The national early warning radiation monitoring network has been well established both for airborne and seawater monitoring using NaI detectors and GM probes. The network consists of 22 airborne stations installed and operated across the country, and 1 seawater probe in the Andaman Sea. Several technical criteria and infrastructure readiness, such as internet connection, site security, natural disaster, site access, were well taken into consideration when siting. Gamma dose rates and identified gamma-emitting radionuclide data are transmitted in nearly real-time to the national data center at Office of Atoms for Peace for further data analysis. Data from several selected stations have been shared the ASEAN Radiation Data Exchange Platform (ASEAN-RDEP) and IAEA International Radiation Monitoring Information System (IRMIS) to ensure timely notification and to provide supporting data to ASEAN MSs and IAEA MSs for more effective decision making process during a nuclear or radiological emergency. OAP is planning to install and operate the Noble Gas Detection System early 2026 under the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty (CTBT).
column118: There is a gamma dose rate monitoring network operational in the countryThere is an environmental monitoring network of automatic monitors for gamma-ray spectrometry of aerosols and/or for gaseous iodine in the laboratory's countryThe national early warning radiation monitoring network has been well established both for airborne and seawater monitoring using NaI detectors and GM probes. The network consists of 22 airborne stations installed and operated across the country, and 1 seawater probe in the Andaman Sea. Several technical criteria and infrastructure readiness, such as internet connection, site security, natural disaster, site access, were well taken into consideration when siting. Gamma dose rates and identified gamma-emitting radionuclide data are transmitted in nearly real-time to the national data center at Office of Atoms for Peace for further data analysis. Data from several selected stations have been shared the ASEAN Radiation Data Exchange Platform (ASEAN-RDEP) and IAEA International Radiation Monitoring Information System (IRMIS) to ensure timely notification and to provide supporting data to ASEAN MSs and IAEA MSs for more effective decision-making process during a nuclear or radiological emergency.
column121: The national radiation monitoring program has been established and is being implemented on a routine basis. Environmental samples such as air particulate, fallout, soil, sediment, fresh water, seawater, and grass, and food including milk, rice, vegetables, meats, and seafood (fish, squid, mussel, and shrimp) are collected from various areas across the country with close collaboration with other governmental agencies and universities. Radioactivity from natural and artificial radionuclides in those samples are measured using HPGe Gamma Spectrometry, LSC, Alpha Spectrometry, and Proportional Counters. In addition, radiation dose rates are measured using OSLs. Radiation dose and radiological risk assessment are performed using radioactivity data in conjunction with other site specific data, such as consumption and inhalation rates, and predictive models. Obtained data are recorded in the database for future use both in peace time and in a nuclear or radiological emergency.
column122: The technical capability in radiation dose assessment in human and non-human biota in both normal and emergency situations needs to be further enhanced.
column123: Office of Atoms for Peace (OAP), Ministry of Higher Education, Science, Research and Innovation.
column126: Yes. Thailand has national regulatory limits for radioactivity in food and drinking water based on the Atomic Energy for Peace Act B.E. 2559 (2016) and Ministry of Public Health regulations, in accordance with IAEA and WHO guidelines.
column129: Priority radionuclides include Cs-137, Co-60, K-40, H-3, Sr-90, and natural radionuclides (U-238, Th-232, Ra-226). Preferred matrices are soil, water, and food (e.g., rice, vegetables, and milk powder).

column132: The ALMERA network provides valuable support for laboratory quality improvement and capacity building. Continued collaboration, technical guidance, and training are highly appreciated.

Regarding Section 7.1:
As the Roshydromet network, we conduct regular environmental radioactivity monitoring around nuclear facilities, outside the supervised area, within a 100-kilometer radius.
Kindly note that our measurement techniques involve analyzing the ash residue of a filter material, which consists of polymer fibers applied to a fabric (gauze) substrate used for air sampling.

column81: Using membrane treatment technology to rapidly remove ions from water to meet the pretreatment requirements for tritium measurement, thereby achieving rapid detection of tritium in water.
column82: For the rapid detection of trace radioactive cesium ions in water, especially in seawater, we have applied a self-developed membrane material that can rapidly and selectively adsorb and retain radioactive cesium ions.
column83: Using rapid membrane technology to replace traditional pretreatment methods such as low-efficiency distillation, ion exchange, and adsorption.
column84: In the future, the technology of "rapid enrichment of radioactive ions in water using membrane methods" will advance in the directions of material precision, process intelligence, system integration, and application scenario-specific development. At the material level, it will shift from general-purpose membranes to specialized membranes "tailor-made" for specific radioactive ions. The separation process will evolve from passive filtration to intelligent separation that is actively responsive and controllable. System design will also progress from single membrane components to integrated equipment combining pretreatment, enrichment, detection, and regeneration functions. In terms of application, it will further expand from laboratory research to customized solutions for different water bodies (such as seawater, wastewater, and groundwater) and diverse usage needs (such as emergency response, real-time monitoring, and resource recovery).

column31:
I can provide comprehensive training in the following interconnected fields, with a focus on both theoretical principles and practical data analysis:
1. Radiochemistry measurment inculding Sample Preparation Techniques: Methods for NORM sample and Radiochemical Yield Determination
2. Gamma-Ray Spectroscopy inculding Detector Physics & Operation: Principles of HPGe detectors and Energy and Efficiency Calibration, Spectrum Analysis: Peak identification, area calculation, and uncertainty analysis.
3. Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS)
Instrumentation & Interface, Detailed understanding of the plasma source, interface region, and mass analyzer, sample preparation, Use of external calibration, internal standardization, Data Analysis & Quality Control
4.Trainee Accommodation 
our capacity to accommodate trainees is flexible depend on the type of training and time.

column21:
GLP Laboratórios specializes in ionizing radiation testing. It was founded in 2015 with the goal of becoming a leading private laboratory in the field of radiometric testing, boasting state-of-the-art equipment for a variety of ionizing radiation tests. GLP offers a broad range of radiometric analysis services and operates in the food, environmental, mining, oil and gas, and research and development sectors. Its main areas of activity are:

-Alpha Spectrometry
-Gamma Spectrometry
-Liquid Scintillation
-Gaseous Flow Proportional Counter
-Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry

The laboratory is accredited by the INMETRO General Accreditation Coordination Office according to ABNT NBR ISO/IEC 17025:2017, under CRL 1266. It is a research laboratory accredited by ANSN - National Nuclear Safety Authority, to operate as a Radiation Facility, under registration number 17525, and for analytical techniques, under registration number 18309.

column122:
•	Develop mobile capability to detect gaseous radioactive iodine in air (portable air sampler with a charcoal filter) + related sampling protocols.
•	Develop an internal preparedness plan for laboratory operation in an emergency situation, taking into account the increased number of incoming environmental and food samples with radioactive contamination. The plan should outline the methods for storing samples and avoiding contamination of the laboratory facilities.
•	Improve SGL radiological analytical capacity by acquiring back-up counting systems for gamma and alpha spectroscopy.
•	Re-establish laboratory capabilities in monitoring Sr-90 in foodstuffs and H-3 in drinking water, in view of planned operation of NPPs in the region.
•	Review food and mixed diet sample preparation procedures and harmonise with best international practice.

column81:
-We participated in EURAMET EMRP ENV57 project (European Metrology Research Project), with 16 Metrology Institutes and Organisations, to develop faster, more reliable and traceable measurement procedures for airborne radioactivity concentration, dose rate and ground contamination data in routine operation as well as in the case of radiological emergency. In the related work package of the project, faster, more accurate and reliable methods to determine activity concentrations of U, Th, Pu, Sr radioisotopes and Am-241 in air filters were developed. In addition, the effectiveness of a Compton suppression detector system in lowering the minimum detectable activity of 241Am in air filters was evaluated and the counting statistics with the suppression counting mode was improved.
-Rapid determination of strontium-90 in seawater with proportional counters.
-A modified method for rapid determination of Y-90 in seawater with liquid scintillation counting.
-Validation of a newly adopted chemical method for determination of 226Ra and 228Ra activities in water and shrimp samples.
-Synthesis and characterisation of CaAlg polymer by gamma radiation, investigation of optimum adsorption-desorption conditions and its use as adsorbent in determination of 210Pb activity
column82: -Development of Dowex/HBr/HNO3 Extraction Chromatographic Method for Determination of 210Pb Activity with Proportional Counter

column127: At the moment there is no national monitoring programme for radioactivity in nationally-produced food. However, there is a work carrying out on this subject, so in the near future there will national monitoring programme.
column128: At the moment there is no national monitoring programme for radioactivity in imported food. However, there is a work carrying out on this subject, so in the near future there will national monitoring programme for imported food.

column17: Environmental Research
column21: All the staff is trained in gamma-ray spectroscopy measurement of environmental samples. We run two labs, one in Bucharest-Magurele in IFIN-HH and the other one underground, in a salt mine in Slanic-Prahova, 100 km North from Bucharest. At any moment, we can extend the number of trained staff to at least 10 people.
column25: Training Materials and Resources (e.g., standard operating procedures (SOPs), manuals, documentation)
column31: 1. We can organize training courses on gamma-ray spectroscopy in both labs, either in IFIN-HH or in the underground lab in Slanic-Prahova. 2. We can organize training courses on radiation dosimetry in both locations, either in IFIN-HH or in Slanic-Prahova. In the underground lab the radiation dose rate is about 1.4 +/- 0.3 nSv/h. In the institute, we have a specialized department in training people in different areas of nuclear techniques and, from this point of view, I consider that we can offer up to 6 months that can be offered in one year, but I have to mention that for the moment I'm not very sure about the man*month we could offer for training. I will have a more precise answer after May 15th.

column121:
Yes. Environmental radioactivity monitoring in Kenya is also undertaken through several programmes coordinated by national institutions:

KNRA: Oversees national environmental radiation monitoring and dose assessment to the public, including baseline surveys around potential radiation sources and border monitoring using Radiation Portal Monitors (RPMs).

Kenya Meteorological Department (KMD): Participates in atmospheric monitoring and emergency preparedness under the national radiation emergency response framework.

National Environmental Management Authority (NEMA): Coordinates environmental surveillance and environmental impact assessments for licensed facilities.

Kenya Bureau of Standards (KEBS) and Kenya Medical Research Institute (KEMRI): Occasionally undertake radioanalytical testing of food, water, and materials for compliance and research purposes.

IAEA-supported projects (e.g. RAF/7/011, INT/9/263) have also contributed to regional environmental monitoring and capacity building.
column122:
1. Institutional and Legal Interface (Coordination Gap)Description:  lack of clearly defined, harmonized roles between KNRA and the Environmental Regulator (NEMA) concerning environmental radiation oversight.
 - Lack of clear interface and documented protocols to ensure seamless data sharing, regulatory authority, and joint response planning for environmental radiation issues between KNRA and other relevant agencies (e.g., water, health, mining).

2. Limited Human and Financial Resources: Challenges often include:Staffing: Insufficient number of trained personnel for field sampling, data interpretation, and quality assurance.Equipment: The need for specialized, highly sensitive equipment for low-level detection, which is expensive to purchase, maintain, and calibrate.
- Need for adequate financial and human resource allocation to fully fund the comprehensive monitoring plan and continuous capacity building (e.g., training in advanced alpha, and beta spectrometry, and data management).

column132: KNRA appreciates the continued support of the ALMERA network in strengthening environmental radioactivity monitoring capabilities. Although the national laboratory is currently not fully operational, this survey provides an important opportunity to assess existing capacities and identify future areas for collaboration, training, and technical assistance.

Environmental Sampling: One person is responsible with some support of other person
Gamma Spectrometry: Four staff members are responsible for sample preparation and measurement, and one staff member is in charge of data analysis and reporting.
Alpha Spectrometry: Two staff member performs radiochemical preparation and measurements, while another is responsible for analytical interpretation and reporting.
Gross Alpha/Beta Measurements: Two staff member handles sample preparation, one conducts the measurements, and one is responsible for data analysis and reporting.
Tritium Analysis: Three staff members are assigned to sample preparation, and one staff member is responsible for measurement, data analysis, and reporting.
Researcher in Radiometric Measurements: one person
Head of Units: Two for managing activities

column131:
The requested activities to be organised by the ALMERA network include:
•	Proficiency testing (PT) exercises for environmental samples (water, soil, vegetation, food, biological matrices) and matrix from mines and miling industry
•	Interlaboratory comparison (ILC) studies for key radionuclides
•	Provision of reference materials (RMs) for calibration and quality assurance
•	Training and capacity-building workshops for participating laboratories
Data evaluation and performance reporting to monitor laboratory proficiency

Published the following peer-reviewed papers related to NORM analysis:
  - Seo, H.C. et al. (2025). A comparative evaluation of 222Rn sealing materials for 226Ra analysis by gamma spectrometry. Environmental Technology & Innovation, 36, 104063.
    - Lee, H.W. et al. (2023). Experimental optimization of physicochemical factors for spontaneous deposition of 210Po using a newly designed deposition kit. Applied Radiation and Isotopes, 198, 110760.
    - Lee, J.H. et al. (2023). Effective separation method for uranium and thorium after borate fusion to minimize matrix influences in naturally occurring radionuclide materials. Journal of Radioanalytical and Nuclear Chemistry, 332, 829–838.
    - Lee, J.H. et al. (2023). Assessment of radiological impact on the surrounding environment and biota for phosphogypsum waste stockyard in Korean facility. Environmental Monitoring and Assessment, 195, 767.
    - Lee, J.H. et al. (2023). Accurate measurement of uranium and thorium in naturally occurring radioactive materials to overcome complex matrix interference. Applied Radiation and Isotopes, 193, 110649.
    - Ryu, J.H. et al. (2022). Rapid sequential determination of 222Rn and 226Ra in drinking water by liquid scintillation counting. Talanta, 239, 123141.
    - Ryu, J.H. et al. (2021). Experimental characterization of an alpha spectrometer for optimizing operational parameters affecting energy resolution and detection efficiency. Journal of Radioanalytical and Nuclear Chemistry, 330, 1263–1272.
    - Lee, J.H. et al. (2021). Preparation and evaluation of new reference materials for naturally occurring radioactive materials (NORM): Zirconium silicate, bauxite, and phosphogypsum. Applied Radiation and Isotopes, 170, 109525.

Registered several patents related to NORM analysis:
    - Chae, J.S. et al. (2025). Metal element concentration device.
    - Chae, J.S. et al. (2024). A device for sealing and storing radon.
    - Chae, J.S. et al. (2024). Metal element concentrator.
    - Lee, H.W. et al. (2023). Apparatus for collecting kit.
    - Lee, H.W. et al. (2022). Polonium collecting unit, polonium measuring apparatus having the same and polonium measuring method.

column21: We are all nuclear physicists by background. 5 of us have PhDs in nuclear physics and we are professors of fundamental and applied nuclear physics courses, as well as medical physics and nuclear physics (Nuclear Physics Group). One PhD student is employed as a member of our group and beside him we have 6 active PhD students that members of our group are supervising. We are closely collaborating with Department of Chemistry at our Faculty for complicate sample preparation techniques.

column81:
1. LSC method for Sr90 in water by Cherenkov counting
2. Fast gross alpha/beta screening method
3. Rn-222 in water on LSC
4. Modified ISO method for uranium in water measurements by LSC
5. Ra-226 on LSC
6. Sr-90 in milk samples by microwave digestion sample preparation and LSC measurement via Cherenkov counting
7. The use of efficiency transfer software for gamma spectrometry for low energy radioisotopes
8. The use of ionic liquids to improve the efficiency of detection for different alpha and beta emitters on LSC
9. C-14 in waste water samples with LSC without complicate chemical preparation
etc.
column82: Swipe sample analysis on LSC
column83:
Further testing of the possibilities to use ionic liquids in LSC measurements.
Improvement of results for HPGe measurements of samples containing uranium.
The use of mathematical calculations, simulations and AI in gamma spectrometry for the analysis of nuclear and other radioactive materials.
column84: Since we don't have radiochemistry lab for sample preparation most of the methods that we develop are relatively fast since the sample preparation is usually minimal. At the moment we don't have exact plans of development of new rapid methods for particular radioisotopes but we are open for any proposals.

column97: Certified standard solutions purchased from Radioisotope Centre POLATOM (when available) or from foreign laboratories (NPL, Czech Metrology Institute, NIST…) are used. Certified reference materials (e.g. Moss soil, IAEA 447; Billberry powder containing Sr-90, IRMM) are also used if they are available and achievable. Sometimes samples obtained during laboratory intercomparisons are also used to run some tests.
column99: For each new developed method the validation parameters (such as linearity, repeatability, trueness, selectivity, etc.) are determined using certified reference solutions, or, where possible, certified reference materials. The laboratory takes part in national and international proficiency tests at least once in every accreditation cycle--that is, once every four years--for each accredited method used. The laboratory also takes part in proficiency tests for non-accredited methods. Reproducibility tests (intra-laboratory) are also run for accredited methods according to the annual schedule. The measuring equipment--Liquid Scintillation Counter counters, gas-flow proportional counters, alpha spectrometer, gamma spectrometry systems(?)--are tested and calibrated with appropriate reference sources and solutions (control charts are also run and kept). Other equipment: Laboratory balances are calibrated by an external company (most often the balance manufacturer service) with certified weights. Some are also legalised by the Polish national metrology authority (Central Office of Measures), which certifies that the measuring instrument meets the requirements. Internal testing is also performed before each weighing. Automatic pipettes are calibrated internally according to the manufacturer’s instructions (in compliance with EN ISO 8655 standard) by gravimetric method using a balance with appropriate sensitivity. The pH-meters are tested with buffer solutions of a known pH value and calibrated with certified pH-buffer solutions.

column110:
Around nuclear facilities
For research
In emergency situations
column116: There is a network of: 13 ASS-500 stations owned by the Central Laboratory of Radiological Protection, that continuously sample atmospheric aerosols on filters and perform spectrometric determination of the content of individual radioisotopes on a weekly basis. There are also 9 stations operated by the Institute of Meteorology and Water Management (IMiGW), 7 of which conduct the continuous measurement of ambient gamma dose rate and the continuous measurement of total and artificial alpha and beta activity of atmospheric aerosols. The stations also measure total beta activity in 24-hour and monthly samples of total fallout, and  determine the content of Cs-137 (by a spectrometric method) and Sr-90 (by a radiochemical method) in cumulative monthly samples of total fallout from all 9 stations once a month.
column118: There is a national network of early warning stations for radiation contamination, consisting of the 13 ASS-500 stations described in the previous section, as well as 58 automatic Permanent Monitoring Stations (PMS) managed by PAA which operate under the international systems of the EU and of the Baltic Sea States. These stations conduct ongoing measurements of the power of the spatial dose equivalent H*(10), ambient gamma dose rate and spectrum caused by radioactive elements in the air and in the ground, and basic weather parameters (precipitation and ambient temperature). The 9 stations of the Institute of Meteorology and Water Management (IMiGW) also conduct continuous measurements of ambient gamma dose rate and take measurements of the activity of atmospheric aerosols and total precipitation. There are also 13 auxiliary stations of the Ministry of National Defence (MON) that perform measurements of ambient gamma dose rate.
column121:
Emergency exposure situations: 
in cases of radiation emergency, intervention measures are taken based on whether the incident is occurring within the area of a given organizational unit (on-site emergency incidents), or for those incidents with impacts reaching beyond the organizational unit ('regional' and 'national' emergency incidents, including those of cross-border effects). The head of the given entity, a provincial governor or a minister of the interior are in charge of eliminating the hazard and the consequences of the incident, depending on the scale of emergency.  
Around nuclear facilities: radiological monitoring on the premises and in the vicinity of the Świerk Nuclear Centre is conducted by our laboratory (that is, the Radiation Protection Measurements Laboratory of the National Centre for Nuclear Research) according to a monitoring programme approved by the President of PAA. There are additional independent specialized centres selected annually by the President of PAA in the vicinity of the Centre which also carry out monitoring duties. Radiological monitoring on the premises and in the vicinity of the National Radioactive Waste Repository (KSOP) is conducted by the Radioactive Waste Management Plant and by the nearby laboratory commissioned by the PAA’s President. 
Existing exposure situations (e.g. uranium legacy sites): the 'Program of radiological monitoring of areas degraded due to uranium ore extraction and processing' has been implemented at the former uranium ore plants since 1998. In 2018 the following measures were undertaken: measurements of radioactive alpha and beta isotopes in drinking water (from public water intakes) within the territory managed by the Association of Municipalities of the Karkonosze Region, as well as in surface and underground water (outflows from underground workings); and the determination of radon concentration in water from public intakes, in water supplied to residential premises, and in surface and underground water (outflows from underground workings).

column81:
1-Determination of Gross Alpha and Gross Beta Radioactivity in Water Samples Using Liquid Scintillation Counter (LSC)
2-Determination of Tritium 3 H in Water samples by Liquid Scintillation Counting (LSC) 
3- Determination of Uranium in Water samples by Alpha Particles Spectrometer. 
4- Surface Scanning and Semi-Quantitative Elemental Analysis of Powders and Solid Materials Using SEM-EDS (EDX)
5- Elemental Analysis in Aqueous Solutions Using Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectrometry ICP-OES
6- Elemental Analysis of Environmental Samples Using Wavelength Dispersive X-Ray Fluorescence (WD-XRF)
7-Determination of Chemical Structure and Phase Identification of Crystalline Material Samples
8- Determination of Radionuclides Activities in Different Samples Using a Manually Developed Calibration Curve with a High-Purity Germanium (HPGe) detector 
9- Determination of Radionuclides Activities in Different Samples Using a Certificate file Calibration with a High-Purity Germanium (HPGe) detector
column82:
Surface Scanning & Semi-Quantitative Elemental Analysis (SEM-EDS/EDX)

Elemental Analysis in Aqueous Solutions (ICP-OES)

Elemental Analysis of Environmental Solids (WD-XRF)

Chemical Structure & Phase Identification of Crystalline Materials (XRD)
column83:
•  Lower MDAs & faster TAT: Optimize sample prep and counting to reduce detection limits and deliver rapid EPR screens.
•  Automation & throughput: Introduce autosamplers/enrichment skids (LSC), automated resin cleanup (alpha-spec), and batch workflows for HPGe/ICP-OES/XRF.
•  Geometry/matrix harmonization: Standardize counting geometries and matrix corrections (density/self-absorption) across γ-spec and XRF.
•  Robust calibrations: Maintain geometry-matched CRMs/check sources, hybrid efficiency curves (HPGe), and matrix-matched XRF/ICP calibrations with routine verification.
•  Cross-tech confirmation: Establish targeted cross-checks (e.g., U by α-spec ↔ ICP-OS; γ-spec ↔ XRF where applicable).
•  Uncertainty & QC: Method-specific uncertainty budgets, control charts, and corrective-action tracking aligned to ISO/IEC 17025.

Standards from NPL, E&Z, HTSL etc

column99:
All
We have either produced in-house or purchased appropriate Quality Control materials that are run with every analytical batch whether accredited or not, with the exception of some very short lived nuclides. 
We run certified standards with every analytical batch to both assure the efficacy of the process, analytical and counting equipment.
Counting equipment is regularly recalibrated against either certified reference sources or specific geometries spiked with known amounts of relevant radionuclides.

column114: Stations for weekly air sampling are located in Retz, Graz, Straß, Bregenz, Salzburg, ALt-Prerau, Innsbruck (high.V), Linz (high.V), Wien (high.V), Klagenfurt (high.V); weekly sampling stations for iodine are located in Linz, Klagenfurt, Wien, Innsbruck. Precipitation collectors sampling monthly are located in Graz, Bregenz, Innsbruck, Linz, Salzburg, Eisenstadt, Klagenfurt, Retz, Wien. Surface waters are sampled at the following locations: Mur/Spielfeld (cont.), Mur/Spielfeld monthly, Bodensee/Bregenz every 2 months (6 per year), Inn/Erl monthly, Inn/Martinsbruck monthly, Rhein/Bangs every 2 months (6 per year), Rhein/Fußach monthly, Donau/Aschach monthly, Donau/Jochenstein monthly, Drau/Schwabegg continuously, Drau/Schwabegg monthly, Inn/Ingling monthly, Lavant/Lavamünd monthly, Salzach/Oberndorf monthly, Donau/Jochenstein quarterly (once every three months), March/Hohenau (STRA) weekly, Donau/Hainburg monthly, Donau/Nussdorf monthly, Leitha/Nickelsdorf monthly, March/Hohenau monthly, March/Markthof monthly, Thaya/Alt-Prerau monthly, Thaya/Bernhardsthal monthly. Drinking water is sampled monthly at the following locations: Graz, Innsbruck, Linz, Bregenz, Eisenstadt, Klagenfurt, St. Pölten, Salzburg, Wien. Mixed drinking water samples are taken in Wien every 3 months (4 per year). Milk (Cow) samples are taken every two months (6 samples per year) at the following locations: Aflenz, Bleiburg, Eibiswald, Kötschach-Mautern, Spittal a/d Drau,  Obersaifen, Reichenfelsh, Deutschlandsberg, Feldkirch, Kals, Möggers, Pinswang, Schwoich, Telfs, Waidring, Zell am Ziller, Ampflwang, Ebensee, Elixhausen, St.Johann im Pongau, Feldkirchen, Maishofen, Mittersill, Oberes Mühlviertel, Pruggern, Reichraming, Reichraming, Schardenberg, Horitschon, Oberwart, Reichenau, Traunstein, Ulmerfeld, Ampflwang. Milk samples are taken monthly in Wien. Mixed samples are taken annually in the following locations: Kötschach-Mautern, Feldkirchen, Mittersill, Möggers, Oberwart, Pruggern, Traunstein, and Waidring. sewage treatment plant monthly Wien, Linz, Salzburg, Innsbruck
